I. Circumstancesoftheconflict
1. Though long presented as a development model, C8te d'Ivoire has been undergoingpoliticaland social turmoil since the militarycoup of December 1999. A ten-month military transition was characterized by a number o f mutinies and destabilization attempts accompanied by social tensions andincreased insecurity. Despite the Forum for National Reconciliation in 2001 and the establishment o f a Government of National Union in August 2002, destabilization attempts persisted. In this context, the militarycoup attempt o f September 19,2002 escalated into a full-blown rebellion,
2. Since September 2002, the country has been divided into two, with the rebellious Forces Nouvelles (FN) holding the northern half and Government the south. This de facto partition has had a serious economic, social, security and humanitarian impact, including massive population displacements, many civilian and military casualties, and the interruption o f the public administration and social services delivery inthe north.
3. Responding to the crisis and increasingrisks of regionalspillover, intensive diplomatic efforts have been deployed internationally and regionallyto resolve the conflict. After West-Africa and French lead efforts, the Marcoussis Peace Accord (January 2003) has provided a general framework for the resolution o f major issues of contention, but implementation has been uneven and the new government o f national reconciliation initial progress were faced with renewedpolitical tensions during 2003-04. Mr. Mbeki, President of South Afiica, temporarily succeeded in getting the Ivorian parties to agree on an action plan and a new timetable to implement the peace accords, However, highlevels o f distrust between the two groups remained and timetables agreed to were not adhered to. The peace process accelerated as o f October 2005 with the adoption o f UNSecurity Council resolution 1633l delaying elections by a year (they are now scheduled for end-October 2006) and establishing a new Transition Government under Prime Minister Banny. These and other recent developments have given grounds for renewed optimism and a credible peace process appears now to be underway.
11. HumanitarianImpact
4. Although large scale fighting lasted for only a short time, the social and humanitarian impact has been severe, causing a prolonged and steady decline of living conditions. Up to a million people were displaced (mostly women and children) and poverty incidence i s estimated to have gone from 38% to 42-44%. Health, education and agricultural services have been disrupted, although some improvement has been registered inthe past year. Inparticular, health services inthe northern and western parts of the country were reduced to minimal levels while schooling was intempted for over half a million students and only resumed with NGOs support in February 2004. 5  production has decreased and cost o f transportation has risen substantially as a result o f roadblocks. Human rights violations are common on both sides o f the confidence zone and repeated concerns havebeenraised by ONUCI as well as human rights organizations.
5. The condition of children in particular raises serious concerns.NGOs have identified many children who have been separated from their families as a result o f the crisis, while the number o f child soldiers i s estimated to be at least 4,000. Since September 2003, the armed forces o f the Forces Nouvelles (FAFN) have officially banned the use and hrther recruitment o f minors, and agreed to start releasing those identified by UNICEF. A similar process was initiated with militias inthe West, but the resumption o f hostilities in November 2004 probably reversed the trend at least for a while.
111. EconomicImpact
6. The economic impact of the conflict has been dramatic. Real output declined by close to 2.5 percent over 2002-03. Some modest recovery has taken place since, with real growth estimated at about 1.8 percent each year, mostly thanks to higher cocoa exports and increased oil production. Since 2001, the last pre-crisis year, real GDP per capita has fallen cumulatively by almost 10 percent. Transparency has deteriorated, the fiscal situation i s strained, and internal and external arrears have substantially increased. As there are still no regular fiscal flows across the demarcation lines, the country remains de facto cut intwo.
7. With tightening and curtailment of bank lending and the prolonged insecurity in many areas, the climate for private sector activity remains depressed. Bankbranches inthe interior and inthe conflict zones have closed and lendingoperations are being directed toward other UEMOA countries. Lingering insecurity, barriers to the free flow o f goods across the national territory, and limited availability of bank credit to the private sector make for a difficult climate for a quick resumption o f private activity. The crisis inNovember 2004 had a very negative impact on industrial production and has drastically reduced the government revenue base. External trade with the sub-region has also been disrupted.
IV. GovernmentResponse
8. Humanitarian Response. According to the Ministry o f Solidarity and Social Security, displaced persons have been registered at state-run social centers in areas under government control, but only a very small fraction actually went to register. The Ministry receives donations from institutions and individuals, and gives them to various structures for distribution to internally displaced persons (IDPs). These structures include reception centers, where some IDPs have been accommodated, and social centers, where they are registered and given assistance. However, they do not assist the host families, which carry the heaviest burden by providing food and shelter for the majority o f displaced persons.
6  9. Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration. As soon as a formal and effective cease fire was declared, the Government o f National Reconciliation undertook the first initiatives to put into effect a program for the Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (DDR) o f ex-combatants, and asked for World Bank assistance. In May 2003, a workshop that included members from both sides, the government and international experts resulted inan extensive outline or "road map" Cfeuille de route) for a DDRprocess, which laidthe basis for further discussions that would eventually arrive at a formal DDR program. The main principles and steps o f the actual disarmament, demobilization and reintegration (DDR) have been agreed upon in a Joint Operations Plan for DDR on January 9, 2004. The national program for the disarmament, demobilization and reintegration o f ex-combatants and for community rehabilitation (PNDDR/RC) and a very detailed chronogram were agreed by the forces in Yamoussoukro in M a y 2005. However, it has not been possible to launch the DDR process as planned and it was only in May 2006, when the logistical details for the parallel implementation o f the DDR and the national identification could be worked out, that pre-cantonment was officially launched.
10. The national program for the disarmament, demobilization and reintegration of ex-combatants and for community rehabilitation. A National Program for the disarmament, demobilization and reintegration o f ex-combatants and for community rehabilitation (known as the PNDDR/RC) has been developed to provide a comprehensive approach, including links with the dismantling o f militias and the restructuring o f the armed forces. Implementationresponsibility was initially given to the National Commission for DDR (CNDDR), dissolved in June 2005. Presently, overall implementation o f the PNDDWRC i s ensured by a technical entity with the same name created by the Prime Minister inJune 2006 (see section D I1for more information).
11, Rehabilitation and Reconstruction.The lack o f coordination among ministries and agencies concerned has been a serious obstacle to strategic planning for reconstruction. The recently-established Ministry for Reintegration and Reconstruction i s expected to provide unity and purpose to efforts inthis area. The PNDDR/RC adopted a CDD approach in order to obtain quick results in the meantime, but the overwhelming attention given to DDR and lack o f fundinghave limitedprogress.
V. InternationalResponse
12. The response of the internationalcommunity has focused on achieving and maintaining peace. Given its strong links to C6te d'Ivoire and the presence o f large numbers o f French citizens inthe country, the French Government was quick to mobilize its troops and interpose them between the warring parties. The French military operation (Licorne), numbering approximately 4,000 men, initially shared peace-keeping responsibilities with MICECI. In February 2004, the United Nations approved the deployment of 6,000 UNPeace Keeping Force (ONUCI) whose arrival inJune-July 2004
7  greatly contributed to stabilize the situation. ONUCI will be a crucial partner to the DDR process2.
13. Since the outbreak of the crisis, the United Nations agencies have had to make a drastic shift from purely development programs to a rapid emergency response mode. The agencies have reinforced their country teams with emergency personnel and have gradually expanded programs to reach vulnerable populations in the interior in collaboration with international and local NGOs. Emergency interventions included: food aid, food-for-work and food-for-agriculture programs by WFP; various education, health, nutrition, water and sanitation programs by UNICEF; and assistance to third country nationals stranded as a result of the conflict by the International Organization for Migration (IOM). The strategy o f the UN Consolidated Appeals Process (CAI?) for C8te d'Ivoire in 2004 was focusing on a "fragile consolidation o f peace" with an estimated US$60 million necessary to respond to the urgent needs o f over one million displaced people. In 2005, the CAP strategy was revised to "no war-no peace" and called for US$36 million, but only 41% couldberaised. The request for 2006 i s $40 million to address the humanitarian needs o f over 3.5 million vulnerable persons, with healthconcerns beingparamount.
14. The DDR process is supported by multi-lateral and bilateral donors. In addition to supporting efforts to promote national reconciliation and social cohesion, UNDP has provided funding and technical assistance to the PNDDR for a socio- economic profiling o f ex-combatants, an ID system for ex-combatants, and mass-media communication efforts. UNICEF has been active in the reintegration o f child soldiers, having undertaken the delicate steps in collaboration with NGOs and the local authorities to have the first 400 children released by the New Forces. The European Union i s supporting sensitization and communication activities, the demobilization o f child soldiers, the program for the militias and HIV/AIDS-related activities through UNFPA. Japan and Belgium are providing support to pre-demobilization cantonment and demobilization activities, including preparation and operation o f demobilization sites, France, Sweden and Norway are supporting reinsertion and the gender dimension. Denmark is contributing to the DDR process as well as to an effort against the proliferation o f small arms. Total financing provided by donors is expected to be about US$24 million (see Attachment 3 for details on donor contributions).

I. RationaleforBankAssistance
15. Bank assistance would facilitate the stabilization of the situation in CBte d'Ivoire, thereby helpingcreate conditionsunder which CBte d'Ivoire could resume pro-poor social and economic development. Bank involvement would also play a catalytic role for other donors to resume or step up assistance, and for the private sector to restart key economic activities. In addition, implementation of the proposed project, as a part of the overall emergency phase o f the Interim Strategy Note (ISN), is a requirement for the successful resumption o f other projects inthe portfolio, as well as for IMF reengagement with a new program.
16. The benefitsof peace andstabilityin C8te d'Ivoirewould extendwell beyond its borders and would strengthen regional integration initiatives that have been weakened by the crisis. Given the troubled history of West Africa and the pivotal role played by Cbte d'Ivoire in the region, failure to reestablish a climate o f security and confidence in Cbte d'Ivoire could jeopardize the fragile peace o f neighboring Sierra Leone and Liberia, and ultimately destabilize the whole sub-region. The opposite i s also true: if Cbte d'Ivoire i s helped in regaining economic momentum, it i s likely to become again the growth engine o f the sub-region.
17. As shown by experienceelsewhere,the Bankhas a comparativeadvantagein assisting Governmentsimplementdemobilizationand reintegrationprograms.DDR i s a key element o f the peace agreement as well as a critical tool for bringingbelligerent groups to the table and preventing a return to conflict. The Bank also has considerable know-how on community driven development andproductive infrastructure rehabilitation via social funds mechanisms and can bring the required level o f resources relatively quickly under the emergency operation mode. It i s therefore uniquely positioned to facilitate the transition from assistance to development in the shortest time possible, which is crucial to give hope to people and avoid settling into a dependency mentality. Experience o f similar situations has proven the interdependence o f DDR and CDD approaches, focusing on the groups that are most likely to destabilize the situation as well as on communities that have bothborn the efforts o f war andbeen ravagedby its effects.
11. Elementsof the BankResponse
18. The Bank's ISN focuses on limited, short-term objectives by promoting macroeconomic stability and improving economic governance. It is envisaged to cover a period o f about twelve months (July 2006-July 2007) and aims at addressing the most urgentpost-conflict needs. To this end, the ISN i s built around three basic pillars: (i) supporting the creation o f a security and institutional environment suitable for elections; (ii) mitigating pressing economic and social costs resulting from the current crisis; and (iii) safeguarding the economic fundamentals.

C. DETAILEDPROJECTDESCRIPTION
I. Objectives
20. The Project aims at: (i) enhancing the prospects for the stabilization and recovery of C6te d'Ivoire by helping the country address its urgent post-conflict challenges; and (ii)preparing the way for dealing adequately with medium and longer-term reconstruction and development challenges. In particular, the Project objectives are to (a) support the reinsertion and reintegration o f about 45,000 individuals including ex-combatants, child soldiers and special groups3; (b) contribute to the rehabilitation or reconstruction o f the social and economic infrastructure in the communities most affected by the conflict; (c) assist vulnerable groups in (re)starting economic activities; and (d) strengthen social capital throughout the country. This will have a significant impact on reducing poverty and contributing to future economic growth by encouraging IDPs and refugees to resume productive lives, improving access to basic social services, investing in the human capital o f ex-combatants, and enhancing the implementation capacity o fcommunity-based development organizations.
21. Project objectives will be pursued through three components: (a) a demobilization, reinsertion and reintegration (DDR) component as provided for in the Linas-Marcoussis Agreement; (b) a community rehabilitation (RC) component to help build capacity and provide funding for community-based infrastructure, income generation and reconciliation for the groups and localities most affected by the conflict; and (c) an institution building and project management component to support project implementation. It i s important to note that the World Bank project will not finance either the disarmament or the demobilization.
11. DDR ProgramComponent
22. The National Program for the Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration of ex-combatants and for Community Rehabilitation(PNDDWRC) and World Bank Contribution. The DDR component will finance part o f a comprehensive national DDR program (known as the PNDDR/RC), which has been validated by representatives o f the belligerent parties. This program outlines all o f the elements of the DDR process, starting with a substantial exercise in sensitizing all the parties concerned by it (particularly the beneficiaries and the communities o f return), all the way through to the social and economic reintegration of ex-combatants into their communities. The World Bank will finance communication and sensitization activities, as well as the reinsertion and reintegration of ex-combatants, including special programs

23. Sensitization and Communication. Prior to the launching o f the actual DDR process, the PNDDR/RC will conduct a campaign to sensitize both the potential beneficiaries (eligible combatants and special groups) and the communities to which they will return as to the content and implications o f the program, to counter dangerous rumors and secure heartfelt participation. Specific communication activities aimed at reconciliation will be carried out in communities where the return o f ex-combatants may cause tension or hostility. This sensitization and reconciliation service will continue throughout the life o f the program as necessary.
24. Timing. The PNDDRwill cover the whole country. The presence o f over 10,000 internationalpeacekeeping forces will provide sufficient security to carry out the exercise simultaneously throughout the country. The total time to complete pre-cantonment, cantonment, disarmament and demobilization i s expected to be about three months, assuming no unexpected delays.
25. Security. During the period o f pre-cantonment, cantonment, disarmament and demobilization, all army personnel will be confined to barracks. In the areas formerly held by government forces, the police and gendarmerie will be allowed to operate normally and use "the weapons deemed adequate for the situation at hand". Inthe areas formerly held by the FAFN and the "neutral zone", the bulk o f the security will be undertaken by the impartial forces, which will also provide exclusive security for the DDRprocess and sites. For more general civilian policing, contingencies havebeenmade to use mixed patrols o f FANCI, FAFN and impartial forces. In addition, some 600 "police auxiliaries" were trained by ONUCI for deployment in the FN zone during the disarmament and demobilization phase. The cost o f the impartial forces i s being and will continue to be metby France and the contributors to the UNPeaceKeeping Operation.
26. Pre-cantonment and cantonment. This initial stage is crucial for confidence- buildingmeasures as forces will exchange lists o f combatants and munitions. This period will allow sufficient time for the identification process o f combatants to take place. After status verification, each combatant will be registered and submitted to socioeconomic profiling that will serve as baseline information for future re-integration activities. In addition, medical teams will carry out medical screenings to identify serious diseases or impairments that may affect ex-combatants' economic and social reintegration. Voluntary counseling and testing for HIV/AIDS will also be offered. Cantonment sites will be intermediate stops between the pre-cantonment and the disarmament sites, with the purpose o fregulatingthe influx o f combatants into the disarmament sites.
27. Disarmament.Combatants will be called forward to the disarmament sites inunit formation (11 in total) in batches o f more or less 150 per day, with their weapons (hand held only). While the first two stages are under the responsibility o f the local forces, starting with the disarmament phase the PNDDIURC will be in charge with ONUCI providing support and oversight. Therefore the official registration o f armaments will
11  happen on disarmament sites under the supervision o f both PNDDR/RC and ONUCI. Depending on their status and eligibility, combatants will then be transferred to demobilization sites to be formally demobilized, to transit and orientation centers (CTOs) ifthey areminors, andto armybarracks ifthey are ex-servicemen who want to remainin the military.Combatants will be stationed indisarmament sites for one day.
28. Demobilization. Over a period o f about a week in specially prepared demobilization sites, ex-combatants will receive a number o f services. These include the following: 0 Formal demobilization and issuance o f a demobilization identity document (ID). 0 Pre-discharge orientation (counseling) to provide ex-combatants with critical information about project benefits, reintegration opportunities, health issues, civic rights and duties (including women's legal rights), etc. Special modules will be offered for female and disabled ex-soldiers targeting their special reintegration needs. 0 Transport organized by the PNDDWRC from the discharge centers to the regional DDRoffices inthe regiono ftheir choice.
29. Eligibility.All those requesting participation inthe IDA-fundedprogram will be required to sign a declaration accepting the terms and conditions o f such participation. The IDA funded re-insertion andre-integration program will be open to: 0 All those (male or female) recruited after September 19, 2002 into the fighting forces involved inthe Ivorian armed conflict; 0 All individuals under the age of 18 that are considered "child soldiers" as defined by the Cape Town Principles concerning child soldiers; 0 The widows and orphans o f combatants killedthe duringthe conflict.
30, Reinsertion. Transitional safety net assistance will be provided by the Government to support ex-combatants for a limited period following their return to civilian life. To support this effort, the Project will reimburse a positive list o f imports for up to US$39.6 million equivalent. The transitional safety net has been calculated by the Ivoirian government to be the cash equivalent o f a defined basket o f basic goods (e.g., household items, clothing and cooking utensils) and services (e.g., children's education) enabling the beneficiary family unit to re-establish a civilian household. It has been set at 499,500 CFA (close to US$l,OOO equivalent per beneficiary). A first tranche equivalent to 25 percent o f the total will be paid upon arrival at the regional DDR office, immediately after discharge from the demobilization site, and two subsequent tranches will bepaid 45 days and 90 days after the first tranche.
31. Reintegration.Economic and social reintegration assistance will be provided to help ex-combatants establish sustainable livelihoods and encourage appropriate use o fthe reinsertion assistance. The following guiding principles will apply: (a) minimize market distortions and maximize beneficiary choice, (b) provide assistance that leads to sustainable livelihoods, (c) involve communities o f settlement and foster reconciliation, and (d) to the extent possible, benefit the wider community. 0 Economic reintegration. Ex-combatants will be equally eligible irrespective o f rank or former military affiliation and they will be allowed to choose their reintegration
12  destination freely. Assistance will be offered in different forms, including: information, counseling and referral services; vocational training, apprenticeship schemes and educational opportunities; employment; provision o f seeds and tools. 0 Social reintegration. Specific activities will include: (a) information and sensitization o f ex-combatants, communities and society-at-large through outreach services, including training o f counselors, (b) specialized counseling, and (c) strengthening o f community services.
32. Special Groups for Reintegration. Three groups will receive particular attention to facilitate their social and economic reintegration: female ex-combatants, widows and orphans o f combatants, and combatants who have been disabled as a result o f the conflict. A premise i s that these groups, and especially female ex-combatants, have strengths and experiences that will help facilitate their reintegration into mainstream social and economic life. The PNDDRRC also recognizes, however, the needfor special support. This will include access to: (i) specialized counseling; (ii) assistance to establish peer-support groups; (iii) medical treatment and rehabilitation; and (iv) support from special programs inresponse to women's needs.
33. Child Soldiers4. Child ex-combatants among armed groups and forces are estimated to be only about 4,000 but they will need priority assistance. The PNDDRRC will work hand in hand with the relevant government ministries, UNICEF (as lead agency) and specialized NGOs. The child soldier program has been established by experts based on current best practice and has benefited from the experience o f a pilot program financed by a Post-Conflict Fund grant. The guiding principle i s to secure the release o f all children associatedwith the fighting forces and to promote as far as possible their earliest re-unification with their families. Child soldiers will be separated from the adults and the mainstream DDR program as soon as presented to the program. They will be taken to special transit and orientation centers (CTOs) for children where experts will assess their needs and define the best approach for re-integrating the child into society. This may require lengthy detoxification and other psychological support, but the ultimate goal i s to return the children to their family -- on no account are the CTOs to become permanent orphanages. Tracing services will endeavor to find the child's family. Older children may be suitable for independent group placement. Some may require support to return to school, others may be more appropriately orientated towards vocational training, or even directly into jobs.
111. RC ProgramComponent
34. Overview. This component aims at meeting the short to medium-term needs of returning rehgees/IDPs and the communities most affected by the conflict by using a CDD approach. Its activities are meant to complement those financed by the restructured projects in the Bank portfolio, and will be closely coordinated with such projects. Through sub-project grants, the RC component will support the following activities: (a) reconstruction, rehabilitation and re-equipment o f community level infrastructure, (b) support to vulnerable groups (re)starting income generating activities, and (c) restoration

Implementation arrangements o f the RC component draw extensively from best practices and lessons learned from similar interventions in Sierra Leone, Ethiopia, Eritrea and Rwanda, as well as the cumulated experience o f CDD-type operations. In addition, two pilot operations inthe center, north and west financed by grants from the World Bank Post Conflict Fund have made it possible to test and refine the proposed mechanisms.
35. Sub-projects qualifying for support under the R C component will be developed and implemented inaccordance with the following principles (see also Attachment 4): (a) enhance the opportunities for self-reliance o f displaced and rehgee populations, as well as war-affected communities; (b) foster stabilization, equality, trust building and reconciliation through a community-based approach; (c) strengthen local capacity to implement and manage reconstruction, rehabilitation and development activities; (d) promote awareness and sensitivity for gender equity and the protection o f the specially disadvantaged (e.g., children, widows, the disabled and the elderly); (e) maximize grassroots participation and input in the sub-project cycle; and (9 promote an integrated approach to resettlement and rehabilitation.
36. Sub-component 1: Reconstruction and rehabilitation of community infrastructure. Infrastructure damaged or looted during the conflict will be rebuilt, repaired and refurbishedin accordance with the preferences expressed by the community, usinga CDD approach. This means that communities will be responsible for all stages o f sub-project implementation, with support from NGOs or other specialized entities as needed. As the experience o f conflict i s often accompanied by feelings o f powerlessness and confusion, allowing beneficiaries to have as much control as possible over their sub- projects will contribute to the healing process. Sub-projects may include rehabilitating or equipping collective infrastructure such as schools, health centers, bridges, markets, and water supply systems inthe communities hardest hitby the conflict.
37. Sub-component2: Supportto incomegeneratingactivities.The primary target o f this sub-component will be vulnerable groups such as female-headed households, youth at risk, and IDPshefugees willing and able to go back to their communities o f origin. Services provided will be geared toward puttinghouseholds and individuals back on their feet through the provision o f small grants for, among others, equipment and training to restart pre-war activities, and in certain cases initiate new income-generating activities. Support to these groups will be channeled primarily through the community, andtechnical support agencies will provide supervision and assistance.

The project has been designedina collaborative fashion, by building on reviews and assessments of key socio-economic and other factors that have andwill influence the emergency situation, with the aim o f laying the conditions for sustainable recovery. V. Benefits
72. The key benefit of Bank assistance would be to acceleratethe stabilization of the situation in C6te d'Ivoire, thereby helping create conditions under which CGte d'Ivoire could resume pro-poor social and economic development. Stability and rule o f law would help prevent the extension o f the conflict and its multi-faceted impacts to its fragile neighbors; it would also facilitate the regional fight against epidemic diseases. The conflict in CGte d'Ivoire has overflowed to jeopardize development and even security in neighboringcountries; stability could return this well-endowed country to its role as an engine o f growth for the sub-region.
73. Immediate assistance is also essential for the sake of C6te d'Ivoire's seventeen million people. Humanitarian assistance on an extended basis breeds dependence rather than self-reliance, grievance rather than acceptance and moving on.

This project would provide resources to move from assistance to development and pave the way for restructured and new projects inthe Bank portfolio. Inaddition, support by the Bank would contribute to a comprehensive framework for other donors, thus laying the grounds for a concerted effort towards sustainable reconstruction and the returnto normal andproductive lives.
VI. Risks
74. The Bank's active engagement in Cate d'Ivoire during this period of crisis is a high-risk, high-profile and potentially high-gain enterprise. The greatest risk, however, i s failing to support the nascent normalization process and missing a window o f opportunity for stabilizing a key country in an unstable region. Thus, while there i s no guarantee that civil war will not erupt again or that the process o f inter-Ivorian dialogue will not lead to a Government that has limitedcommitment to development, the risks o f doing nothing are much greater. O f course, the risks associated with actively engaging in an uncertain environment must be carehlly considered. In this sense, the Interim Strategy Note (ISN) identifies the main risks associated with a Bank presence in CBte d'Ivoire and suggests mitigating responses. More specific risks associated with the proposed operation are explored below.

While there has been significant progress toward the implementation o f the Linas-Marcoussis Agreement, and more in general toward a return to normalcy, the path has been far from smooth. Leaders on both sides have at times behaved in a way that cast serious doubts over their true commitment to peace, and it i s clear that not all stakeholders are equally supportive o f a negotiated solution. Yet, there are strong internal and external forces pushing toward peace. Many religious groups, community associations andjust ordinary citizens continue to play a conciliatory role while regional leaders and the whole o f the international community have repeatedly called on the two sides to make a serious effort for the implementation of the peace agreements. The World Bank, as a member o f the International Working Group established to monitor and facilitate the implementation o f peace agreements, has the opportunity to support the stabilization process in a very effective manner.
Reversal of the peace process and resumption of hostilities. Many observers agree that sustainable peace will not be secured until the DDR and national identification processes are completed, the militias are disarmed and dismantled, and free and fair elections are held. The intervention o f peacekeeping forces has proved crucial in restoring order on a number o f occasions and their presence i s expected to last until the situation i s less fragile. The efforts o f the international community, combining soft diplomacy with more assertive stances (UN sanctions), have also been effective in keeping the peace process moving. In particular, careful monitoring o f the arms embargo has discouraged continued armament on both sides o f the confidence zone.
27  0 Destabilization and absence of security. The militias (mostly inthe West but also in Abidjan) can play a significant destabilizing role. As stated in the Pretoria agreement, they should be disarmed and dismantled in parallel to the DDR process. In addition, the circulation o f large numbers o f light weapons may result in increased criminality, especially in the immediate post-disarmament period. Thus, after the beginningo fthe DDR,the capacity anddeployment o fthe security forces will be crucial to the sustainability o f the disarmament o f various groups. Therefore a solid and feasible restructuring o f the security sector i s also critical. The successful implementation of the security plan for Abidjan and the recent launching o f a national program against the proliferation o f light weapons could be an important contribution to improved security.
Insufficient implementation capacity. Both public and private sector capacity in CGte d'Ivoire have been weakened by administrative and educational crises and governance problems, while the massive displacements caused by the conflict may result in an uneven distribution o f skills and limit needed labor mobility. This situation may prove particularly problematic in view o f the decentralized nature o f the project, which will require the presence o f competent and dynamic individuals throughout the country both in regional DDR and RC offices and as implementing partners. The project will select staff and implementingpartners on a competitive and transparent basis, but also make technical assistance available if needed. The monitoring & evaluation system will facilitate careful monitoring o f implementation progress, so as to be able to spot and address problems as they arise. In addition, the community approach adopted for many o f the project activities has proven effective in situations where capacity was arguably lower than inCGte d'Ivoire.

E. FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC JUSTIFICATION
78. Overall Justification. Quick, tangible improvements in living conditions and the returnto normal life are paramount for the resumption o f growth. Duringthe immediate post conflict period o f two to three years, rapid progress on economic recovery and reconstruction will be essential to the long-term economic development o f C8te d'Ivoire. Luckily, the conflict has been relatively short-lived and therefore adjustment to a normal way o f life should not pose major problems. Inparticular, displacedpopulations have not had the time to develop the dependent mentality typical o f long-term residents o f refugee camps and transitional shelters. Similarly, many combatants have been recruited fairly recently and therefore their return to civilian life should not be very problematic. Experience from post-conflict situations throughout the world suggests that the most effective way to encourage the quick resumption o f peaceful social and economic activities, and therefore o f the development process, i s through emergency D D R R C projects, which deal with the most visible and disturbing aspects o f conflict - large numbers o f armed personnel and extensive movements o f population fleeing from violence.
79. Analysis of Alternatives. The project design reflects the accumulated wisdom o f previous post-conflict operations. The underlyingproject concept o f providing assistance to the internally displaced, refugees and ex-combatants, as well as to the receiving communities, i s based on best practices and experiences gained in similar IDA member countries and post-conflict situations, and it is deemed appropriate for achieving the development objective o f the project. The training and employment efforts directed at
29  ex-combatants are also based on successful Bank and other donor agency experiences in numerous countries, while the RC component draws on experience with social funds, CDD and natural disaster reconstruction projects. Inaddition, the pilot activities financed bythe Post Conflict Fundhave provided crucial context-specific information.
80. Cost Analysis. It was not possible, nor is it required, to conduct a cost-benefit analysis for this project. The project design, therefore, i s based on cost-effectiveness, attempting to minimize costs without forfeiting quality. Whenever possible, existing structures will be used rather than buildingup parallel systems; for example, payments of reinsertion allowances will be done through existing financial institutions at the local level and PNDDWRC regional offices will be housed in government buildings. Administrative costs have been contained by limiting the number o f Project staff and relying on NGOs and other private and public agencies that already have a field presence inthe target zones. Inaddition, economies of scale will be realized by having a number o f services shared by both components (procurement, financial management, communication, monitoring and evaluation), while preserving the needed independence o f the DDR and R C activities.

ExecutiveSummary
As part of the preparation of the Emergency Demobilization, Reintegration and Community Rehabilitation Project, a full financial management assessment has been carried out in accordance with the Financial Management Practices Manual issuedby the Financial Management Sector Board on November 3, 2005. The main objectives o f the assessment were to determine whether: (a) the PNDDR/RC has adequate financial management arrangements to ensure that project funds will be used for the intended purposes in an efficient and economical way; and (b) PNDDRRC financial reports will beprepared inan accurate, reliable and timelymanner; and (c) PNDDRRC assets will be safeguarded.
A Country Financial Accountability Assessment (CFAA) has not yet been conducted in C6te d'Ivoire because the country has been undergoing a prolonged period o f political instability, which began with the military coup in December 1999 and precipitated with the conflict that started on September 19, 2002. This situation has had a severe economical and political impact inthe country.
A Public Expenditure Review (PER) was conducted in 2003 and has concluded that budget preparation was relatively strong but improvements were needed to ensure consistency among projections usedby various ministries and agencies. There is no clear link between policies and resource allocation. According to the PER, the implementation o f the integrated financial management system called SIGFIP has provided some significant benefits in terms o f budget expenditure monitoring and control, inclusion o f donor activities, and strengthened capacity for execution. The SIGFIP system, however, due to its numerous steps, slows down the entire process unduly. Donor funds are reported in the budget, but because o f the war situation, expenditures often deviate significantly from the amounts budgeted with the government giving priority to the payment o f military wages, security equipments, etc. There are also significant payment arrears. The Bank will conduct an integrated PER and CFAA to be started inFY07 and finalized inFY08.
Disbursement of external assistance has been slow. Bank projects experienced a disbursement rate averaging only about 12% over the past five years before suspension, compared to an average Sub-Saharan Africa rate o f about 22%. In part this reflects a difficult, conflict-affected environment, but it i s also a result o f weaknesses in public expenditure management and controls.
The conclusion o f the financial management assessment is that financial management arrangements have an overall risk rating o f high and do not satisfy all the requirements under OPh3P10.2.
To mitigate the country and project risk, a Fiduciary Management Agency (FMA) will be selected to ensure that sound financial management and procurement will be maintained

The FMAwill be equipped with a software appropriate to the scale and nature o fthe emergency program, integrated into the project M I S in a modular way. The project will have similar book accounts to those for other IDA-funded projects.

This was especially true with respect to the cocodcoffee sector, contracts between the public and private sectors, and management o f petroleum. Since June 2004, C6te d'Ivoire has accumulated significant arrears on its debt obligations towards the Bank, and on November 1, 2004, it fell into non-accrual status. The authorities have remained current on their obligations to the Fund. They have accumulated about $300 million in arrears to the World Bank as o f June 1, 2006. However, the government is seeking to rapidly enhance the financial accountability framework in order to: reimburse arrears, mitigate fiduciary risk inpublic
43  expenditure management; achieve economy, efficiency and effectiveness in the use o f public funds; enhance transparency and accountability.
Riskassessmentandmitigation
The objectives o f the project's financial management systemare to: 0 Ensure that funds are used only for their intended purposes in an efficient and economical way; 0 Ensure that funds are properly managed and flow smoothly, adequately, regularly and predictably inorder to meet the objectives o f the project; 0 Enable the preparationo f accurate and timely financial reports; 0 Enable project management to monitor the efficient implementation o f the project; and 0 Safeguard the project assets and resources.
Moreover, the following features are recommended for a strong financial management system: 0 The PNDDR/RC should have an adequate number and mix o f skilled and experienced staff both at the central and the decentralized levels (Regional Offices); 0 The internal control system should ensure the conduct o f an orderly and efficient payment and procurement process, and proper recording and safeguarding o f assets and resources; 0 The accounting system should support the Program requests for funding and meet its reporting obligations to fund providers including The Government o f CGte d'Ivoire, IDA, other donors, andlocal communities; 0 The system should be capable o f providing financial data to measure performance linked to the output o f the project; 0 An independent, qualified auditor should be appointed to review the Program's financial statements and internal controls; 0 The first year, semi annual technical and financial audits will be conducted to ensure coherence between the physical and the financial implementation o f the Program; and 0 An independent qualified Fiduciary Management Agency should be selected through a transparent process to ensure sound FMsystem.

Institutionalandimplementationarrangements
The PNDDRRC will be responsible for the overall implementation o f the project. A Fiduciary Agency will be selected to manage World Bank funds. Based on experience from other post-conflict projects inAfiica, management o f the DDR and R C components will be kept separate, with separate Designated Accounts and separate component coordinators.
The objectives o fthe FMA are to: 0 Ensure that funds are used only for their intended purposes in an efficient and economical way; 0 Ensurethat funds are properly managedand flow smoothly, adequately, regularlyand predictably inorder to meet the objectives o fthe project; 0 Enable the preparation of accurate and timely financial reports; 0 Enable project management to monitor the efficient implementation o f the project; and
46  0 Manage procurement, including purchases o f goods, works, and consulting services;
Regional offices will be established for both components for more efficient implementation. A good financial management system will be put in place at the decentralized level to ensure sound management o fproject funds.
AccountingArrangements andInformationSystem
For IDA resources, the FMA will maintain books o f accounts in accordance with accounting standards acceptable to the Bank. The books o f account to be maintained should include: a Cash Book, ledgers, journal vouchers, fixed asset register and a contracts registers. The books o f accounts will be maintained on a computerized system. A list o f accounts codes (Chart of Account) for the project should be drawn up and should match the classification o f expenditures and sources and application o f funds indicated in the Financing Agreement. The Chart o f accounts should be developed in a way that allows project costs to be directly related to specific work activities and outputs o f the project.
Concerning the overall Program, the PNDDRRC will maintainbooks o f accounts for the activities financed by the Government and the other donors in a format, content and periodicity that will ensure provide qualitative and timely consolidated financial statements to be audited. The audited consolidated financial statements submitted to the Bankshould reflect all project activities, including those financedbyother donors andthe Government.
Books o f Accounts to be used for the Program will be opened and a Chart o f Accounts will be completed inaccordance with the requirement inthe FinancingAgreement.
Staffingarrangements
The FMA will be staffed by experienced and qualified personnel with relevant background in donor-funded projects. It has been agreed that the staff will comprise o f one senior financial management specialist, one accountant, one senior procurement specialist and hidher assistant. At the decentralized level, FMA will be represented inthe nine RC regional offices will berepresented byone accountant for eachregion, including the office in the District o f Abidjan. The regional accountants will maintain books o f accounts for IDA resources. Regional accountants could be used for cross support in different regional offices if deemed necessary due to Program's cycle and/or activities. A financial management specialist will be appointed at the PNDDRRC as a focal point to help inmaintaining the information link between the FMA and the PNDDRRC. He/She will be responsible for consolidating the Program's financial statements
FMA staff as well as PNDDWRC staff will be trained as appropriate in the following areas (i)Financial Management including internal controls, information system and computer applications; (ii) disbursementprocedures; and (iii) procurement guidelines and procedures. This can be arranged in consultation with the Senior Financial Management
47  specialist and the Senior Procurement Specialist based respectively in Abidjan and Ouagadougou during the implementation period o f the project.
To make sure that the project i s effectively implemented, the FMA and PNDDR/RC will ensure that appropriate staffing arrangements are maintained throughout the life o f the project.
InformationSystem andAccounting
The FMA will maintain a consolidated budget and accounting system for the duration o f the project including all sources o f funds. To that end, the PNDDR/RC i s already will be equippedwith a computerized and integrated financial management system appropriate to the scale and nature o f the emergency program and capable o f recording and reporting in a timely manner the project operations.
InternalControlandFinancialManagementManual
The project internal controls (including processes for recording and safeguarding fixed assets) are documented in the Financial Management and Accounting Manual (FMAM) o f the PNDDR/RC. A supplemental Financial Management Manual will have to be preparedto take into consideration the specific concerns o f regional offices. The FMAM should be a living document that can be updated to strengthen the internal control system during the whole life o f the project. The procedures used by the project to maintain its records at all levels o f implementation will be documented in the FMAM. These will include the requirement for cross references to supporting documentation in the SOE supporting schedules in order to facilitate the inspection o f these schedules and improve the maintenance o fthe project's records.
The FMAM describes the accounting system: major transaction cycles o f the project, funds flow processes, the accounting records, supporting documents, computer files and specific accounts in financial statements involved in the processing o f transactions. The FMAM also includes the financial reporting process, project budgeting procedures, procedures to be used for the replenishment o f the Designated Account and auditing arrangements.
The FMA will ensure that an adequate internal control system is in place at the central and regional levels. The project will have an internal audit unit which will be headed by an internal auditor who has already been selected on a competitive basis and in conformity with Bank procurement procedures. The role o f the internal auditor is clearly spelt out in the terms o f reference used for the selection. His role will include ensuring that the FMA i s executing all its activities in accordance with the relevant TORSand contract.
48  DisbursementArrangements/ Flow of Funds
Flow of Funds. The Project will have two Designated Accounts, one covering expenditures related to the DDR component (excluding the transitional safety net) as well as general project management expenditures, and the other covering expenditures related to the R C component. Both Designated Accounts will be located at the BCEAO and will have advance accounts in a Commercial Bank that will be managed by the FMA in accordance with Bank operational guidelines. Furthermore two separate accounts will be established at the BCEAO for the project's quick disbursing component, and the government counterpart funds. The IDA funds will only transit in the BCEAO DesignatedAccounts and will be immediately transferred by the Treasurer to the FMA in advance accounts opened in commercial banks, acceptable by the Bank and the Government. The government has agreed to use this special procedure for PNDDRRC to allows project funds to by-pass several steps o f the cumbersome regular national procedures .
FMA will transmit withdrawal applications to the Directorate o f Public Debt for submission to IDA. Withdrawal applications will be submitted along with statements o f commercial Banks and Designated Accounts opened at the Central Bank. All disbursements will be initially transaction based and given the large size o f the Designated Accounts, namely CFAF 1.6 billion and CFAF 1.5 billion for the above captioned components, respectively, there will be a minimum application size o f USD 550,000 equivalent for any payment other thanDedicated Account replenishments.
Should it become necessary to establish regional sub-accounts (30 days advance), an effort will be made to accommodate such need, provided that the Bank approves the accounting system put in place for such accounts. The PNDDWRC will coordinate all withdrawals and replenishment o f the Designated Accounts with the FMA. Funds Flow arrangements will be as follow: (i) IDAwill make an initialadvance disbursement fkom the proceeds o fthe Grant by depositing into the Government o f CGte d'Ivoire operated Designated Accounts held at the reliable commercial bank inU S dollars; (ii) Actual expenditures will be reimbursed through submission o f Withdrawal Applications and against Statements o f Expenditure that will be approved in accordance with internal control measures inthe FMAM; and (iii) All expenditures o fBank's funds will bepaidbyFMA inaccordance with the approval mechanism documented inthe FMAM.

The timely availability o f funds and the smooth flow o f funding will be critical elements for the government to implement the DDR process within the planned timeframe. The Project will therefore use a quick disbursement mechanism in accordance with Bank's guidelines for Emergency Recovery Operations. Under this provision, the government will be eligible for reimbursement o fup to a total o fUS$39.6 million equivalent against a positive list o f imports. Retroactive financing will be possible for expenditures that have been incurred up to four months prior to the expected date o f signature o f the financing agreement. A joint GovernmentBanks team will be formed to compile and review the list of positive imports and related procurement documentation. The first payment against a positive list o f imports will consist o f US$10 million equivalent and will be made at effectiveness so as to help cover expenditures for the first tranches o f the transitional safety net for ex-combatants. The second payment of US$10million equivalent will be made when the Government furnishes to IDA evidence inform and substance satisfactory to IDA showing that a random sample o f at least five percent o f the demobilized combatants have received the first tranche o f the transitional safety net with less that a
50  5% error. The third and last payment o f US$19.6 million will be made when the Government furnishes evidence in form and substance satisfactory to IDA showing that a random sample o f at least five percent o f the demobilized combatants have received the second tranche o fthe transitional safety net with less than a 5% error.
FinancialReportingArrangements
The PNDDR/RC will produce quarterly Financial Monitoring Reports (FMRs) and will submit the FMRs to IDA within 45 days after the end o f each quarter. The FMRs will include financial reports, physical progress and procurement information. At a minimum, the financial reports must include the sources and uses o f funds, expenditures by main expenditure classifications, beginning and ending cash balances and other supporting schedules.
The financial reports should be prepared in a structure and detail that facilitate comparison with physical progress. The semi-annual financial statements will comprise but will not be limited to: (i) Statement o f Source and Application o f Funds for the the Program during the current financial year, and cumulatively since the start o f the Program; (ii)the statement o f expenditures (SOEs); (iii)the Dedicated Account StatementReconciliation; and (iv) the Project Account StatementReconciliation and any other financial report deemed necessary and relevant.
ExternalAuditing
The audit report should reflect all the activities o f the Program, including those financed by other donors and the Government, and must be submitted to IDA within six months after the end o f each financial year. The arrangements for the external audit o f the financial statements o f the Program should be communicated to IDA through agreed terms o f reference. Appropriate terms o f reference for the external auditor must be developed and agreed within six months o f Grant Effectiveness.
For the first year, a financial and technical audit will be conducted semi-annually to ensure consistency betweenthe physical and the financial implementation o f the Program and provide opinion on Program's performance. Thereafter, it's assumed that PNDDR will have in place adequate mechanisms to monitor and control physical and financial implementation o f the Program; therefore financial audit will be conducted. Audits will be conducted by independent auditors acceptable to the Bank in accordance with international auditing standards. Audit reports o f such scope and detail agreed by IDA would be submitted to the Bank within 6 months after the end o f the audit period. The auditor will provide a separate opinion on each: (i) the Program financial statements, (ii) the statement o f expenditure (iii) Designated Accounts. The auditor will also provide the a management letter on the internal control procedures outlining recommendations for improving the control system, the accounting and financial procedures as a result o f the audit.
51  Supervision Plan
A supervision mission will be conducted at least twice every year based on the risk assessment of the project. The mission's objectives will include ensuring that strong financial management systems are maintained for the project throughout its life. An SOE review will be carried out regularly to ensure that expenditures incurred by the project remain eligible for IDA funding. The Implementation Status Report will include financial management rating for the project.

doc.repnme: Cote D'Ivoire - Emergency Demobilization, Reintegration and Community Rehabilitation Project
doc.abstracts: The Emergency Demobilization, Reintegration and Community Rehaibilitation Project for Cote D'Ivoire aims at providing needed immediate support for: (a) demobilizing and reintegrating about 45,000 individuals including ex-combatants, child soldiers and special groups, (b) rehabilitating or reconstructing social and economic infrastructure in the communities most affected by conflict, (c) restarting of economic activities by vulnerable groups, and (d) strengthening social capital throughout the country. The Project includes a quick disbursing mechanism that uses a positive list of imports to generate counterpart funds to finance rapid project implementation.
